contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=June 2008}} '''Internal bleeding''' (also called '''internal [[hemorrhage]]''') is a loss of [[blood]] that occurs from the [[vascular system]] into a [[body]] cavity or space.<ref name="isbn0-8036-1559-0">{{cite book |author=Taber, Clarence Wilbur; Venes, Donald |title=Taber's cyclopedic medical dictionary |publisher=F a Davis Co |location= |year=2009 |pages=1200 |isbn=0-8036-1559-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> It can be a serious [[medical emergency]] depending on bleeding rate and location of the bleeding (e.g. brain, stomach, lungs). It can potentially cause [[death]] and [[cardiac arrest]] if proper medical treatment is not received quickly. == Causes == A number of [[medical conditions]] may lead to internal bleeding. Common causes include [[Trauma (medicine)|trauma]], various [[Pathology|pathological]] conditions and [[Complication (medicine)|complications]] of medical therapy. Common locations include the [[gastrointestinal tract]], the [[aorta]] and [[intracranial hemorrhage]]. === Trauma === Internal bleeding can be caused by [[blunt trauma]] such as high speed [[acceleration|deceleration]] in an [[automobile accident]], or by [[penetrating trauma]] such as a [[Ballistic trauma|ballistic]] or [[stab wound]].<ref>Nicholas S. Duncan, Chris Moran, "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S187713270900195X Initial resuscitation of the trauma victim]", ''Orthopaedics and Trauma'', Volume 24, Issue 1, February 2010, Pages 1–8</ref> === Pathological conditions and disease === A number of pathological conditions and diseases can lead to internal bleeding. These include [[blood vessel]] rupture as a result of high [[blood pressure]], [[aneurysms]], [[esophageal varices]] or [[peptic ulcers]].<ref>Edward W. Lee, Jeanne M. Laberge, "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1089251604000484 Differential Diagnosis of Gastrointestinal Bleeding]", ''Techniques in Vascular and Interventional Radiology'', Volume 7, Issue 3, September 2004, Pages 112–122</ref> Another common cause of internal bleeding is [[carcinoma]] (cancer), either of the gastro-intestinal tract, of the lung, or more rarely of other organs such as the [[prostate]], [[pancreas]] or [[kidney]].<ref>Edward W. Lee, Jeanne M. Laberge, "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1089251604000484 Differential Diagnosis of Gastrointestinal Bleeding]", ''Techniques in Vascular and Interventional Radiology'', Volume 7, Issue 3, September 2004, Pages 112–122</ref> Other diseases linked to internal bleeding include [[scurvy]], [[hepatoma]], [[Hepatocellular carcinoma|liver cancer]], Autoimmune [[Thrombocytopenia]], [[ectopic pregnancy]], malignant [[hypothermia]], ovarian [[cysts]], [[Vitamin K]] Deficiency, and [[hemophilia]] and [[malaria]]. Some viruses may cause a type of internal bleeding called [[viral hemorrhagic fever]], such as the [[Ebola]], [[Dengue fever|Dengue]] or [[Marburg virus disease|Marburg]] viruses, but these are rare.<ref>M. Bray, "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780123739445003035 Hemorrhagic Fever Viruses]", ''Encyclopedia of Microbiology'' (Third Edition) 2009, Pages 339–353</ref> === Iatrogenic === Internal bleeding could be an [[iatrogenic artifact]] as a result of complications after [[Surgical operation|surgical operations]] or medical treatment. Some [[medication]] effects may also lead to internal bleeding, such as the use of [[anticoagulant]] drugs or [[antiplatelet drugs]] in the treatment of [[coronary artery disease]].<ref>Jan Pospisil, Milan Hromadka, Ivo Bernat, Richard Rokyta, "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010865013000271 STEMI—The importance of balance between antithrombotic treatment and bleeding risk]", ''Thrombosis'' , Volume 55, Issue 2, April 2013, Pages e135–e146</ref> == Prognosis == Internal bleeding can be serious for two reasons: * the blood can compress organs and cause their dysfunction (as can occur in [[hematoma]]) * when it does not stop spontaneously, the loss of blood will cause hemorrhagic [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]], which can lead to [[brain damage]] and death. If there is pressure, it may lead to death or a brain hemorrhage. == Terminology == Cases of internal bleeding are usually called [[hemorrhage]], even though the term is general to all kinds of bleedings. A minor case of internal bleeding results in [[ecchymosis]], or a bruise: blood expands under the skin, causing discoloration. == Notes == {{reflist}} [[Category:Injuries]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]]{{Wikibooks|First Aid|Internal Bleeding}}
